Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(x) \\) defined in the complex plane, where \\( z(x) = e^{ix} \\). We study the integral transformation \\( Z(s) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-st} z(t) \\, dt \\) over complex variable s and real variable t.

If the function \\( z(x) \\) is modified by a scaling factor \\( \\alpha \\) such that \\( z(x) = \\alpha e^{ix} \\) without further transformation, will the calculated transformed function \\( Z(s) \\) at s = i still result in the same value as for \\( z(x) = e^{ix} \\)?
Explanation: The scaling factor \\( \\alpha \\) will scale the integral by the same factor because \\( Z(s) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-st} (\\alpha e^{ix}) \\, dt \\) becomes \\( \\alpha \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-st} e^{ix} \\, dt \\), which modifies the magnitude of the integral and consequently the value of \\( Z(s) \\).
